fact_check_explanation_title: Housing, oil revenues, and teachers: factchecking Prime Minister's Questions
fact_check_explanation_summary: We've factchecked claims from Prime Minister's Questions on benefits, housing, oil prices and teachers.

fact_check_explanation_title: Why is the government accusing the BMA of lying?
fact_check_explanation_summary: The government has accused doctors' union the BMA of lying to its members over the pay offered in a new junior doctors' contract. Here's why.

fact_check_explanation_title: The state of private rented homes
fact_check_explanation_summary: While 30% of private rented homes aren't rated 'decent' according to a government standard, the proportion failing it because of health and safety is 17%.

fact_check_explanation_title: Would restricting in-work benefits to EU migrants reduce immigration?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Sir Stephen Nickell has said that restricting access to benefits wouldn't have much impact on EU immigration, Iain Duncan Smith says it would.

fact_check_explanation_title: Are junior doctors getting a pay cut?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Weekend pay is a major sticking point in negotiations between junior doctors and the government. What do we know about what the proposals will mean for pay?

fact_check_explanation_title: Onshore wind: how much investment would be affected by early closure of the subsidy?
fact_check_explanation_summary: We look into some of the available evidence on money that's been invested in onshore wind projects.
The Prime Minister will today announce reforms to the prison system in England and Wales. We've factchecked the key claims we've heard this morning.
The prison population was about 45,000 in England and Wales in 1990 and 1991 and is now about 86,000.

fact_check_explanation_title: Does re-offending cost Â£13 billion a year?
fact_check_explanation_summary: That's the upper range of an estimate for 2007/08.
We check the Prime Minister's figures on self-inflicted deaths and injuries in prison.

fact_check_explanation_title: How many prisoners re-offend within a year of release?
fact_check_explanation_summary: Close to half of all prisoners in England and Wales will commit another criminal offence within a year of being released.
We checked the Question Time panel's claims about migrants' benefits, Norway and the EU, English speakers, and the Northern Powerhouse.
